climbs.name: Unknown bolted route between Number Eight and Dolly

content.description: This route is between number eight and dolly and is a bolted line.  I don't know the grade or any other info on it, can't find it in a guide, if you know more let me know
content.protection: 8 bolts with a two bolt anchor with chains
content.location: Between Number Eight/Number Eight variation and Dolly

content.description:
Short but sweet!  Scramble up the blocky terrain to the overhanging roof crack and commence jamming!  The crack varies from hands to fists.

Sandi Epeldi's book gives this route 5.11C, but when we climbed it we felt that it wasn't harder than 5.10.  The jams are solid the whole way, and if you look around there are a few key feet that help.  Whatever the grade, it's a fun climb with great pro!
content.protection:
Pro from 0.75" to 3".  Anchor is 1 bolt that can be backed up with gear.

To get down, you can top out and walk over to the Muchachas Borrachas anchors and rap from there.  Be careful when leaning over to clip them.
content.location: This route is located on the other side of the talus field at the right end of the Tall Cliffs.  Once you cross the talus it should be obvious.

content.description: Fun arete/face climb with a steep finish.
content.location: This route is located 25 ft. to the left of Jet Screamin Hooter Queens and starts just right of a small free-standing column.

content.description: Crack to chain anchor, exit right when crack ends.  Anchors over the top of the prow
content.location: Left of painted Number eight, crack on left side of the dihedral

content.description: Easy Stemming leads to an interesting sequence towards the top . . .
content.protection: 5 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.  Supposedly this one was retro-bolted . . .
content.location: The bolted line 50 feet right of Beta Junkie

content.description:
A fun, yet appropriately named, route.  Climb the column without using the cracks on either side.

A tricky start on thin holds through a roof (crux) leads to the first bolt.  If you don't want to commit to the moves before the first bolt, you can climb the crack next to the column, clip bolt #1 from there, then downclimb and start the route with the rope clipped above.

After the initial crux, easy but fun jug pulling up the vertical column commences past several more bolts before reaching a bird-poo covered ledge (Hence the name).

From the ledge, clip the last bolt and head up and slightly left onto steep rock.  You may want to bring some tiny nuts or cams to protect the final awkward step to the right to gain the anchors.
content.protection: 6 bolts, plus a tiny cam/nut or two. 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: The next bolted route to the left of Beta Junkie.

content.description: Scramble up some blocky terrain to the first bolt.  With the first bolt at your neck, pull the crux moves that are a bit trickier than they look.  Easy slab climbing past the next two bolts leads to the anchor.
content.location: This climb is across the talus field at the right end of the Tall Cliffs.  It is about 40' right of a prominent roof crack (Rosy Palms).

content.description: Lichen covered face and crack just right of Muchachas Borrachas.  Wide finger crack slightly off the deck with multiple protectable cracks as you ascend widening near the top right of Muchachas Borrachas anchors
content.protection: Standard Rack to 3 inches and set of nuts with two bolt Muchachas Borrachas anchors
content.location: Just right of Muchachas Borrachas bolt line

content.description: Dihedral with a wide (off-width hands) crack on right side, watch for loose rock
content.protection: Top rope off anchors over top of lip
content.location: Just left of My Stinky Hole bolt line

content.description: Finely tuned leading skills recommended, this climb is given a thumbs up in Sandy Epeldi's Boise climbs book
content.protection: trad gear to a 1 piton 1 bolt belay
content.location: The tall cliffs between Full tilt boogie and circumciser

content.description: "Climb straight up the serrated face to the Number Eight anchors" -Epeldi
content.location: They say a picture is worth a thousand words.Â  Check out the photo ;)

content.description:
Fun route with some intimidation factor. It climbs better than it looks from the ground. Move up the column face slightly left of the bolt line for several clips before crossing right and up to a fingers/ring-locks crack. Plug a piece or two from great stances and then up to another bolt. From here, head left and clip another bolt to protect the crux. I remember finding a nice knee-bar rest here. Fun, bouldery moves lead into an obtuse corner feature and jugs at the anchors.

Also known as

Seppuku

, Hara-kiri is primarily described as the now-abolished Japanese ritual of suicide by disembowelment. The act was performed to allow samurai facing certain death the ability to die with honor and to avoid torture by enemy captors.
content.protection: Bolts, 1-1.5" gear for the crack. Rap hangers.
content.location:
Immediately left of

Beta Junkie

. Look for 3 or 4 bolts leading to a nice crack and a steep finish.

content.description: Climb up the column face to anchors at the top.  Very enjoyable climb..
content.protection: 6 bolts to chains at the top..
content.location: Climb is located toward the very east end of the Tall Cliffs.. Rap off of chains.

content.description: This is a bolted route up the face of a column between Balloon Party and Raptor Arete on the Tall Cliffs, I do not know the name or the grade but can mark the bolt line, please update if you know the grade or name of the route
content.protection: Bolts, ~8 bolts with two bolt anchor with rap rings
content.location: located between Balloon Party and Raptor Arete, ? one column to the east of Balloon Party

content.description: Start on relatively easy slabby pillar on jugs.  Wander up this towards the roof, clipping bolts as you go.  Just before the roof is a cruxy slab move to reach the roof but the business is still waiting.  Crank the roof on surprisingly good holds to the ledge where you can reach the chains.  I recommend going out the central/right side of the roof or you may set yourself up for a nasty whipper.
content.location: Far left side of the tall cliffs.  First bolted climb you see when hiking up.  See picture.

content.description: Dihedral to roof with no anchors
content.location: Two columns right of Circumciser

content.description: This route is toproped from the Thanks for the Mammaries anchors and is just left of the main bolted route.  This route climbs through the dihedral and the splits the crack at the roof, see picture for the line
content.location: Just left of Thanks for the Mammaries

content.description: Climb this basalt column to the top. I find the crux to be the top part of the climb while others find it to be the bottom part of the climb. The route is well protected and fun!
content.location: Take the trail to the Tall Cliffs and it will be on your left. There is a short column block right in front of it.

content.description: "2 bolts and supplementary pro to the Number Eight anchors. Â This line was previously a toprope problem that ended at the Number Eight Left anchors. Â The original finish is probably best avoided due to loose blocks." -Epeldi
content.location: See the photo

content.description: Anyone who can tell me how to actually climb this route gets a gold star...ok, Hard start move fast on small footholds and smearing using undercling hold with right hand. Climb the route near the bolt line using the cracks and legdes. Hand jam and work your way to the face below a huge jug, dyno here and work your way to the steep roof. Side pull on left, stay center, step high left and smear foot on side of roof, stand, reach high right to good hold stem your way to the chains. This route is awesome and is easy to toprope to get it dialed before you lead it. Classic route, exposed at times, fun and well bolted.
content.location: Middle of the Tall Cliffs, 20 feet left of the large painted 8.  See picture.

content.description: Top route climb just right of Thanks for the Mammaries, between the two bolted lines, use Thanks for the Mammaries anchors to TR from
content.location: Just right of Thanks for the Mammaries, just left of unknown bolted route

content.description:
This route offers a unique contrast between its lower and upper sections.

Scramble up some broken choss for ~20 feet until you can step up and clip. The technical crux comes at and above bolt 2 with stems and side-pulls leading to a somewhat difficult third clip.

After this, the route steepens and offers great movement between spaced, positive holds all the way to the top.

Have your belayer watch you closely through the crux as you end up a bit above bolt 2 with the choss ledge not far below.
content.location:
This is the right-most line at the main wall at the Tall Cliffs.

Look for the line of 5 bolts in tan rock starting ~20' from the deck.
